phonegame
Class GameEngine

java.lang.Object
  javax.microedition.midlet.MIDlet
      phonegame.GameEngine
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
public abstract class GameEngine
extends javax.microedition.midlet.MIDlet
implements java.lang.Runnable

The GameEngine forms the core of the game by controlling the gameloop and the painting operations. All games must extend this base class.

Version:
2.0, October 11, 2005, 2.1, April 24, 2006, 3.0, November 17, 2006
Author:
Tim Prijn, Richard Kettelerij & Paul Bergervoet

Method Detail

addEnvironmentMap

protected final void addEnvironmentMap(byte[][] map,
                                       int xPosition,
                                       int yPosition)
Create an environment, also known as a tiled map, based on a two dimensional byte array. This method is especially useful if you want to quickly build a level/map (walls, floor, etc) for a platform- or boardgame.
The images to be used in the map must have been set earlier, using the method GameEngine.setTileImages(String[] imagePaths, int tileWidth, int tileHeight).

Parameters:
map - positions the different tiles in the game. A zero means 'no tile'. A number greater than one means that there is a tile, the image will bet taken from the list of images. The first image is identified with a 1, the second with a 2, etc.
xPosition - the horizontal start position of the map on the screen
yPosition - the vertical start position of the map on the screen

addGameDashboard

protected void addGameDashboard(GameDashboard dash)
Add a game "dashboard" (a.k.a status panel) to the game

Parameters:
dash - an instance of GameDashboard

addGameItem

public void addGameItem(GameItem item)
Add a GameItem to the game.

Parameters:
item - the GameItem to be added

addPlayer

protected void addPlayer(GamePlayer player)
Add a player to the game. Note that the game can contain only one player, however you can change from player at any given time.

Parameters:
player - reference to an object that represents the player of the game

addStepListener

public void addStepListener(IStepListener listener)
Add a IStepListener object to the game. This object will receive a call to it's spepAction method in every cycle of the game loop.

Parameters:
listener - The IStepListener that must be added

changeTile

public final void changeTile(int xindex,
                             int yindex,
                             byte tilenr)
Change a tile in the game world.

Notes

The x and y positions are the indices in the tile-array, not the x and y positions in the world.
A zero value for the tilenumber removes the tile at the given position
The tilenumber is a byte value. It must be smaller than 256. Also you need to use a type cast, when you enter an integer number.

Parameters:
xindex - the x-pos of the tile in the tile array
yindex - the y-pos of the tile in the tile array
tilenr - the new tile number.

clearBackgroundImage

public void clearBackgroundImage()
Clear the background image of the game.
The background will now be the background color, or black if the background color has not been given.

deleteAllGameItems

public final void deleteAllGameItems()
Delete all GameItems from the game, including the player. To be used when you move from a level to the next one.

deleteGameItem

public void deleteGameItem(GameItem item)
Delete a GameItem from the game.

Parameters:
item - the item to remove

existItemsOfType

public final boolean existItemsOfType(java.lang.String type)
Find out if there are any instances of the specified type (GameItem) currently in the game.

Parameters:
type - the class name of the gameitem (without the package name and without .java!)
Returns:
boolean, true if any items are present, false otherwise.

Exit the game (and phone emulator, if running on a PC)

findItemAt

public final GameItem findItemAt(int x,
                                 int y,
                                 int w,
                                 int h)
Find the GameItem is present in an area at given x,y position, with given width and height. This method will return the first item it finds. It will return null if there is no GameItem.

Note: to find the GameItem at a certain point, fill out 1 for width and height. A zero-size area intersects with nothing!

Parameters:
x - x-position of the area
y - y-position of the area
w - width of the area
h - height of the area
Returns:
the found GameItem, or null, if nothong was found.

findTilesAt

public final int findTilesAt(int x,
                             int y,
                             int w,
                             int h)
Find out what tiles are present in an area at given x,y position, with given width and height.

Note: to find the tile at a certain point, fill out 1 for width and height. A zero-width area intersects with nothing!

Parameters:
x - x-position of the area
y - y-position of the area
w - width of the area
h - height of the area
Returns:
a bit pattern indicating the tile numbers that are in the given area. See the collision listener interface to learn m ore about these bit patterns

getItemsOfType

public final java.util.Vector getItemsOfType(java.lang.String type)
Get all instances of the specified type (GameItem) that are currently in the game.

Parameters:
type - the classname of the gameitem (without the package name and without .java!)
Returns:
a list of gameitems of the specified type

getRandomX

public int getRandomX(int width)
Get random x between left edge of world and right edge minus the specified width. In this way you can find a random position for an item of the given width and the item will fit completely into the world.

Parameters:
width -
Returns:
a random x-position

getRandomY

public int getRandomY(int height)
Get random y between top edge of world and bottom edge minus the specified height. In this way you can find a random position for an item of the given height and the item will fit completely into the world.

Parameters:
height -
Returns:
a random y-position

the width in pixels

Get the number of the current step (cycle) in the game loop.

The number of the current cycle (first cycle is nr 0)

Remove an IStepListener object from the List This object will no longer receive step events

resetGameTime

public void resetGameTime()
Reset the stepcounter and clear all alarms.
Note: Use this method when you start a new level or restart the game. Watch out for the correct order: First reset the GameTime, then add new Items, then restart the game again.

run

public void run()
The GameLoop, keeps the game running... Don't call this method yourself! Use startGame() to start the game.

Specified by:
run in interface java.lang.Runnable

                                  int green,
                                  int blue)

Parameters:

green - the green RGB value
blue - the blue RGB value

setBackgroundImage

protected void setBackgroundImage(java.lang.String imagePath,
                                  boolean autoSize)
                           throws GameException
Set the background image of the game.

An image will be fixed to the viewport, it will not scroll when you move the player. Therefore it is best to use a background image when the world is small and the viewport is fixed.

Warning!
Only use background images on fast/powerfull phones. Most older phones (e.g. the Siemens MC60 and a SonyEricsson T630 on which we've tested it) have a hard time drawing large background images.

Parameters:
imagePath - relative path to the image file
autoSize - true, if you what the background image to be scaled according to the screensize of the (target) phone. False if you what the image to maintain it's original size
Throws:
GameException - if the specified image is not found at the given path

setBounds

public void setBounds(int minX,
                      int minY,
                      int maxX,
                      int maxY)
Set the boundaries of this game. If you want the game world to be as big as the screen, you need not use theis method. By default the bounds will be set to the size of the screen. That is: minX=0, maxX=screenWidth, minY=0, maxY=screenHeight.

Parameters:
minX - the minimal horizontal coordinate
minY - the minimal vertical coordinate
maxX - the maximal horizontal coordinate
maxY - the maximal vertical coordinate

setPlayerPositionOnScreen

public final void setPlayerPositionOnScreen(int pos)
Sets the position of the player on the screen. In many games, the game world is bigger than the screen. When you specify the player position, you can make the screen (viewport) move along with the player. The parameter tells how this must be done. For example, you can specify HCENTER or VCENTER, if you want to keep the player more or less in the middle of the viewport, or BOTTOM if you want the player in the bottom of the screen.
Note: if you position the player at one of the edges of the screen, like BOTTOM, this means that you can not move out of the screen that way, but you can move up a bit. How much that is, is specified by setPlayerPositionTolerance.

Parameters:
pos - one of the following combinations: 
  • PLAYER_FIXED

    Viewport won't move. If your world is bigger than the screen, the player can move out of sight on all sides! 
  • PLAYER_TOP, PLAYER_VCENTER, PLAYER_BOTTOM

    Player is at top, center or bottom of viewport. Horizontal positioning is not controled, you can move out of view at the sides! 
  • PLAYER_LEFT, PLAYER_HCENTER, PLAYER_RIGHT

    Player is at left, center or right of viewport. Vertical positioning is not controled, you can move out of view at the top or bottom! 
  •  PLAYER_TOP | PLAYER_LEFT, PLAYER_TOP | PLAYER_HCENTER, PLAYER_TOP | PLAYER_RIGHT

    PLAYER_VCENTER | PLAYER_LEFT, PLAYER_VCENTER | PLAYER_HCENTER, PLAYER_VCENTER | PLAYER_RIGHT
    PLAYER_BOTTOM | PLAYER_LEFT, PLAYER_BOTTOM | PLAYER_HCENTER, PLAYER_BOTTOM | PLAYER_RIGHT
    Combinations of vertical and horizontal positioning. The following image illustrates this type of positioning:

setPlayerPositionTolerance

public final void setPlayerPositionTolerance(double ht,
                                             double vt)
Set the tolerance of the positioning. When tolerance is zero, the viewport moves immediately when the player moves. When tolerance is 1, you can move to the edge of the screen before the viewport moves. Values in between result in a smaller or bigger delay before the viewport moves.
Example: In a left-to right platform game, you may position the player at LEFT, VCENTER. If you set the horizontal tolerance at 0.3, you may move to the right 30% of the screen before the viewport moves along. If you set vertical tolerance at 0.8, you can move 80% of the way up, before the viewport moves up also.

Parameters:
ht - horizontal tolerance, a value between 0 and 1
vt - vertical tolerance, a value between 0 and 1

setTileImages

protected final void setTileImages(java.lang.String[] imagePaths,
                                   int tileWidth,
                                   int tileHeight)
                            throws GameException
Set the images for all tiles that will be used in the game. Do this only once, at start up of the game. If you make a multi-level game, you can create different levels using the tiles in this list.
All tiles must have equal sizes, to be specified in this method.

Parameters:
imagePaths - relative path(s) to the square tile images. Please not that the sequence of the images in this array define the numbers that you can use in your map (so the first image is identified with a 1, the second with a 2, etc).
tileWidth - the width of the tile images that are used (usually 16 or 10 pixels)
tileHeight - the height of the tile images that are used (usually 16 or 10 pixels)
Throws:
GameException - if the specified images are not found at the given paths

setTimer

public void setTimer(int time,
                     int id,
                     IAlarmListener listener)
Add a timer for a GameItem to the timerlist

Parameters:
time - the number of steps that must be taken
id - the identifier of the timer object. If you have several timers, you can give them different id's. The id will be given when the timer rings.
listener - the object that needs to receive the call. This object must implement the IAlarmListener interface.

setViewPort

public void setViewPort(int x,
                        int y)
Set the position of the viewport manually. You must do this if you set the player position in viewport to FIXED. If it is not fixed, it is no use setting the viewport, because the viewport will adjust to the player position.

Parameters:
x - xpos of viewport
y - ypos of viewport

showGameForm

protected void showGameForm(GameForm form)
Displays the given GameForm on the screen.
Important: this method can also be used to display the (original) gameworld, to achieve this you'll need to set the form parameter to null.

Parameters:
form - the GameForm that needs to be displayed, or null if you want to show the gameworld.

                 throws javax.microedition.midlet.MIDletStateChangeException

startGame

public void startGame()
Start the game loop, or restart it after a pause.
Note: Game time (stepnumber and alarms) are not affected.

stopGame

public void stopGame()
Stop the game loop.
